title: Future continuous and future perfect
introduction: Do you know how to use phrases like I'll be studying or I'll have finished? Test what you know with interactive exercises and read the explanation to help you.
rules: We use the future perfect simple (will/won't have + past participle) to talk about something that will be completed before a specific time in the future.
t be + -ing form) to talk about future actions that:
t have + past participle) to talk about something that will be completed before a specific time in the future.
keyPoints: you come out of school tomorrow, I'll be boarding a plane
examples: Do you know how to use phrases like I'll be studying or I'll have finished?
Look at these examples to see how the future continuous and future perfect are used.
In five years' time, I'll have finished studying medicine.
You can visit us during the first week of July.
He'll be staying with his parents for several months while his father is in recovery.
Will you be starting work earlier with your new job?
We use the future perfect simple (will/won't have + past participle) to talk about something that will be completed before a specific time in the future.
The guests are coming at 8 p.
On 9 October we'll have been married for 50 years.
Will you have gone to bed when I get back?
I won't have written all the reports by next week.
By the time we arrive, the kids will have gone to bed.
I'll have finished in an hour and then we can watch a film.
In three years' time, I'll have graduated from university.
